theme: Micro, Small and Medium Enterprise support

abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the Fourth Small Scale Enterprise (SSE)
            Project in Ecuador. Project objectives were to enhance the
            contribution of the SSEsto industrial development through
            the modernization and expansion of SSE production by(a)
            facilitating the access of SSEs to formal credit, (b)
            promoting lending to SSEs by participating financial
            intermediaries (PFIs), (c) providing more focused and
            integrated technical and managerial assistance to eligible
            SSEs and reinforcing coordination among TA providers, and,
            (d) further strengthening the management and technical
            skills of PFIs that provide credit to SSEs. The
            implementation and outcome of the project is evaluated to be
            Partially Satisfactory in this report. The TA aspects of the
            project were partially successful. Borrower performance was
            satisfactory in some aspects of the loan, but deficient in
            the management of Development Fund for Small Scale
            Enterprises and Artisans (FOPINAR)'s financial
            condition. The key lessons learned in this project include:
            1) Apex financial institutions need to appraise the
            financial capacity of PFIs not just at the start of the
            project, but to develop capacity to monitor this continually
            making revisions to the eligibility list as needed; 2) The
            principles of transparency and accountability that
            necessitated the creation of a separate fund (FOPINAR) for
            project implementation need to be reiterated continually by
            the Bank; 3) Bank supervision should have been much more
            effective in monitoring the financial performance and
            accounting practices; 4) TA interventions should be well
            articulated, demand driven and lodged in an agency with a
            clear mandate for providing TA services; 5)  Caps on margins
            charged by the PFIs can be counterproductive; and 6) A good
            evaluation system requires more than a monitoring database.
